title-group.article-title: Movement That Matters Historically: Janet Cardiff and George Bures Miller’s 2012Alter Bahnhof Video Walk

ref.mixed-citation: Miwon Kwon, One Place after Another: Site-Specific Art and Locational Identity (:MIT Press,2004),29.
Rosalyn Deutsche, Evictions: Art and Spatial Politics (:MIT Press,1998).

On the historical development of expanded cinema, see Gene Youngblood,Expanded Cinema(New York: E. P. Dutton, 1970); Chrissie Iles,Into the Light: The Projected Image in American Art, 1964–1977(New York: Whitney Museum of American Art, 2000); and Gabrielle Pedullà,In Broad Daylight: Movies and Spectators After the Cinema, translated by Patricia Gaborik (London: Verso, 2012).

See Grant H. Kester,The One and The Many: Contemporary Collaborative Art in a Global Context(Durham, NC: Duke University Press, 2011); Claire Bishop,Artificial Hells: Participation Art and the Politics of Spectatorship(London: Verso, 2012); Anna Dezeuze, ed.,The ‘Do-It-Yourself’ Artwork: Participation from Fluxus to New Media(Manchester, UK: Manchester University Press, 2012); Lev Manovich, “The Poetics of Augmented Space,”Visual Communication5, no. 2 (2006): 219–40; Mark B. N. Hansen,New Philosophy for New Media(Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 2006); Steve Benford and Gabriella Giannachi,Performing Mixed Reality(Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 2011); Jason Farman,Mobile Interface Theory: Embodied Space and Locative Media(New York: Routledge, 2011); and Adriana Souza e Silva and Jordan Frith,Mobile Interfaces in Public Spaces: Locational Privacy, Control, and Urban Sociability(New York: Routledge, 2012).

See Ronald Azuma, Yohan Baillot, Reinhold Behringer, Steven Feiner, Simon Julier, and Blair MacIntyre, “Recent Advances in Augmented Reality,”IEEE Computer Graphics and Applications21, no. 6 (November–December, 2001): 34–47, www.cs.unc.edu/~azuma/cga2001.
Paul Ricoeur, Memory, History, Forgetting , translated by Kathleen Blamey and David Pellauer (:University of Chicago Press,2004),412.

My definition of affectivity borrows from clarifications proposed by Francisco J. Varela, “The Specious Present: The Neurophenomenology of Time Consciousness,” inNaturalizing Phenomenology, edited by Jean Petitot, Francisco J. Varela, Bernard Pachoud, and Jean-Michel Roy (Stanford, CA: Stanford University Press, 1999), 299, and Maxine Sheets-Johnstone,The Primacy of Movement(Amsterdam: John Benjamins, 2011), 454.

Patricia S. Churchland, V. S. Ramachandran, and Terrence J. Sejnowski, “A Critique of Pure Vision,” inLarge-Scale Neuronal Theories of the Brain, edited by Christof Koch and Joel L. Davis (Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 1994), 23–60.
Alva Noë, Action in Perception (:MIT Press,2004),3.
Ibid., 78.
Ibid., 3.
Ibid., 57.

Maxine Sheets-Johnstone, “Thinking in Movement: Further Analyses and Validations,” inEnaction: Toward a New Paradigm for Cognitive Science, edited by John Stewart, Olivier Gapenne, and Ezequiel A. Di Paolo (Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 2010), 167.
Ibid.
N. Katherine Hayles, How We Think: Digital Media and Contemporary Technogenesis (:University of Chicago Press,2012),1.
Ibid., 69.
Andy Clark and David J. Chalmers, “The Extended Mind,” inThe Extended Mind, edited by Richard Menary (Cambridge, MA: MIT Press, 2010).
Ibid., 29.
Mark Rowlands, The New Science of the Mind: From Extended Mind to Embodied Phenomenology (:MIT Press,2010),16.
Roland Barthes, “La Révolution brechtienne” [1955], inEssais critiques(Paris: Seuil, 1964), 51.

George Bures Miller, “Haus der Kunst: Artist’s Talk—Janet Cardiff & George Bures Miller with Carolyn Christov‐Bakargiev,” April 12, 2012 (published on April 16, 2012), www.youtube.com/watch?v=xMWd50TmuHs.
Brian Massumi, "Notes on the Translation and Acknowledgements," in A Thousand Plateaus: Capitalism and Schizophrenia , Gilles Deleuze and Felix Guattari (:University of Minnesota Press,1987),xvi.

“Affect . . . is the name we give to those forces—visceral forces beneath, alongside, or generally other than conscious knowing, vital forces insisting beyond emotion—that can serve to drive us toward movement, toward though and extension.” See Gregory J. Seigworth and Melissa Gregg, eds.,The Affect Theory Reader(Durham, NC: Duke University Press, 2010), 1.
Eric Shouse, “Feeling, Emotion, Affect,”M/C Journal, 8, no. 6 (December 2005), http://journal.media-culture.org.au/0512/03-shouse.php.
Ibid.
Sheets-Johnstone,The Primary of Movement, 454.
Kaja Silverman, Male Subjectivity at the Margins , (:Routledge,1992),205.
Ricoeur,Memory, History, Forgetting, 412.
